Alcohol unlocked something in my introverted nature early in my 20s, allowing me to be more outgoing, leading me to believe that my experiences and self were bound to the substance forever. In actuality, I reached a crucial fulcrum in life and drinking contributed to a malaise and two years of inactivity when I could of moved on to the adventure I knew in my heart was waiting for me (joining a community called L'Arche, which led to meeting my wife, finding a new home in midwestern city I love, and finding a vocation in social work that brings me fulfillment in relationship that I couldn't find while I was drinking).

I regret that after I divorced, I chose another partner who had a temper and turned out to be horrible to my children. Perhaps a doctor had just given her a dressing-down and told her that she's "only a nurse".  I regret not telling her to stop saying that, and also not telling her that I believe nurses are angels for the work that they do (I really felt that way and still do).  I occasionally think about her and wonder if she stayed in the profession.

That's the short way to say it. I became a poet. I still tried by applying to 3 wonderful colleges and even going to University of Iowa City at 43. But illness and no finances kept me from doing so.

The biggest regret I have is abruptly breaking up with my boyfriend in University, and then rather spitefully having sex with another guy a few weeks later. 

This happened in 1990, when we were both 20. I was immature and impulsive, and at the time I was full of selfish justifications that I have since realized were ridiculous. The truth of how wrong and hurtful I had been eventually sank in, but it was too late to undo the pain I caused. R was a good, sweet, kind, and loving man, the love of my life actually, and I betrayed him. 

If I had a time machine, this would be the ONE turning point in my life that I would go back to, where I would make a whole set of entirely different choices based on knowing what I know now. This one action completely and permanently changed the courses of both our lives, and has had repercussions to this day, more than 30 years later.

I throw this confession"out to the universe. R, wherever you are, I am deeply sorry for all of it.

My biggest regret is losing the love of my life, my boyfriend while I was in college. We were in love and I ruined it by wanting to be polyamorous. He did not want that. I told him he was more important to me than anyone else (which was true), and I told him I would be faithful. But the truth is that I also wanted to explore, and I let myself. Those explorations were never that enjoyable, but he eventually would not put up with it anymore. When he ended things, I was heartbroken and realized the mistake immediately. As I write this, it sounds clearly like a moral regret, but it resonates with me as a boldness regret. I regret not trying that very night to change the situation, to profess my undying love, ask for forgiveness, and ask for another chance. I rationalized that he would not take me back. He had decided. I also regret several other occasions where I could have made a bold declaration to him before we both ended up married to different people and with kids.

My biggest regret is not living in the moment throughout my children’s’ childhoods. I don’t think I knew how. There was a point very early on when I was playing with my youngest, who was about 2 (his older siblings were ~ 4 and 6) that I realized that I should be “in the moment” and not thinking of the many “more important” things on my plate. How foolish of me that I had no idea how important that realization was and what I could have done with it had I paid attention to it. There was no talk at the time of “living in the moment” or “being present”. I went on to bring up my kids with my mind often focusing on matters other than those of the present moment. I regret not really being there for them when I could have made a real difference in their growing years and I regret not fully enjoying the many wonderful moments we had. I was cognizant of having so much, but I didn’t fully understand or appreciate how fortunate I was until it was too late.

I wish I had not become an employee. I had been working successfully as a consultant for the last 7 years in the energy industry when my former boss (who I reported to as a consultant for one company) called me to offer me some work. I had the option to be a consultant or employee and out of fear I chose employee. I was fearful because my client at the time had screwed me over on a contract, my parents were struggling to make ends meat because they hadn’t planned for retirement, and ultimately I wasn’t confident in my own skills and ability to save for retirement. The employee position I took offered a defined pension program that would ensure I had money for retirement, but had I continued to work as a consultant I would have made significantly more money and could have built up my own retirement plan with the help of my financial advisor. This regret has caused me to go into a severe depression and I constantly ruminate on my stupidity.
